The splenic sinusoids are lined by elongated stave cells oriented parallel to the flow of blood. Stave cells are stabilized by perpendicularly-arranged reticular fibres and surrounded by a discontinuous basement membrane.
The spaces between stave cells are only 2-3 m wide, less than half the diameter of a RBC. The blood cells from the sheathed capillaries that enter the splenic cords must pass through these slits in the walls of the splenic sinusoids in order to re-enter circulation. This does not present a barrier to platelets, white blood cells or young, flexible RBCs. However, RBCs lose their flexibility at roughly 120 days and therefore, older RBCs are excluded from the lumena of the splenic sinusoids and are phagocytosed by the macrophages of the splenic cords.
